comments:
This course is designed to provide students with an understanding of the strategic decisions in marketing media and entertainment products. It is a course about developing, financing, producing, marketing and distributing media and entertainment, and the role these functions play in shaping the creative and commercial decisions of media and entertainment companies. Using the case method, the course examines these companies from the perspective of entrepreneurial and multinational organizations in businesses as varied as film, television, music, video games, theme parks and sports entertainment. Marketing of Media and Entertainment is a course that evaluates the global, technological and social landscape of media and entertainment in the context of both the content and distribution side of these businesses.

Students found course material to be very interesting and “valuable to everyday life.” More specifically, the course provided a better understanding of different aspects of interactive media. The course was fast-paced but packed with plenty of real-life knowledge applicable to students’ lives.

Students were generally very pleased with Professor Diamond’s seminar-styled lecture. Some described Professor Diamond as “incredibly engaging” to listen to and able to convey course material in a “clear and exciting way.” One thing to note is that Professor Diamond was seldom available in forms apart from email due to her intense traveling schedule.

Some students thought the grading on cases and especially exams was subjective and not representative of material taught in class. Even though the course was loosely structured by nature of its seminar style, students who found the course material interesting said the three hours always passed by quickly. This class is recommended to majors and non-majors alike.
